Alternative-based accounts of disjunction
7. Alternative-based accounts of disjunction

In the previous section, we saw that recent semantic work has argued
that disjunctions like “\(A\) or \(B\)” should be
treated as generating a set of propositions \(\{A, B\}\) rather than
yielding the classical join of the two disjuncts. The intuition behind
these accounts is that the main function of a disjunctive sentence is
to present a set of alternatives. A disjunction offers
characterizations of (at least) two different possible states of
affairs, and (under certain circumstances) asserts that at least one
of these holds in the actual world. Besides phenomena of free choice
discussed in the previous section, other linguistic facts have been
argued to justify an alternative-based analysis of disjunction. In
this final section, we first introduce the recent inquisitive
semantics as an example of an “alternative-based” system
with a fully developed logic, and then briefly discuss these further
linguistic motivations.
